After Sarah was taken, I found a Sunday School paper that she had done in Sunday School, and it was probably done a month before.
And it asked three questions, and she had written her little answers out.
And the first question was, how do people see that you love God?
And she said, we have a Bible in our house and we have a manger scene at Christmas.
And the second question was, do you tell people about God?
And she had said, no, I'm shy.
And I need you to hear the third question.
How do people know you love God?
And she wrote...

Sarah Elizabeth Pryor got it.
She got it at age three, she got it at age four, she got it at age five, six, seven, eight, and nine.
Barbara Pryor, Sarah's mother.
Sarah would have celebrated her 22nd birthday today.
Her death was confirmed after the positive identification of a skull fragment found a few miles from her Wayland home.
Other stories this afternoon.
Health maintenance organizations could face stiffer regulations in this state.
Acting Governor Solucci has filed a bill that would create a managed care ombudsman to help patients exercise their rights.
Governor Solucci says the legislation will ensure health considerations drive doctors' decisions rather than money.
Legislators around the country are making similar proposals relating to HMOs.
ABC's Bill Greenwood reports on growing criticism of the managed care industry.
With more than a thousand health care bills now pending in state legislatures, the managed care industry sees a distinct link between critical news coverage and a growing public backlash.
A study by the Kaiser Family Foundation found that 65% of the news reports about managed healthcare have been neutral.
But during the past eight years, the number of critical reports more than doubled, jumping from 12 to 28%.
Kaiser reviewed 2,100 news stories, including TV broadcasts, which were found to be the most damaging.
Bill Greenwood, ABC News, Washington.
And a new strain of influenza may be spreading around the country.
The sickness is different from the flus that are covered by this year's vaccine.
They've hit two states so far.
The type A Sydney flu has been found in about 40% of all cases studied by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention since October.
The new flu places the elderly and the chronically ill at greater risk.
WBZ Newstime now at 2.39 and business news is coming up.

For that matter, do we still have a sense of humor in America?
I'm David Brodnoy, Boston University professor and humor specialist Joseph Boskin joins me tonight at 10 to talk about our funny bone right here on WBZ Newsradio 1030.
WBZ News Time is coming up on 2.40 now.
In New England business, Millennium Pharmaceuticals of Cambridge has been granted a patent for what it calls its first patent in the field of predictive medicine.
The patent is entitled, Methods for the Diagnosis of Body Weight Disorders, Including Obesity.
The patent covers methods for diagnosing weight disorders in which the UCPH gene transcript or the UCPH protein level is measured.
That protein discovered by Millennium is involved in energy expenditure and in weight control.
The patent test can be used to help understand the genetic basis of a patient's weight disorder and also to diagnose individuals who are at risk of developing a body weight disorder such as obesity.
And inflation continues to be low.
The Labor Department says the consumer price index rose one-tenth of one percent for the month of December.
All of 1997, inflation at the retail level was up just 1.7 percent, the smallest rise in 11 years.
The December core CPI, that's minus food and energy, rose two-tenths.
Analysts do not expect inflation pressures to build anytime soon, held in check by Asia's troubled economy.
And to check on Wall Street now, the Dow 30 Industrials are up 53 points at 7,700.

This is Neil Chayette looking at the law.
When a football coach runs his students to death, will the coach and the school be held responsible?
That was the question in a case recently decided by a federal district court in South Texas
16-year-old Donald Roventini was participating in the first day of fall football practice, which consisted of more than four hours of intense outdoor physical activity on a hot and humid summer day.
According to the lawsuit later filed by Donald's family, there was no rest, not enough water.
Near the end of the practice, Donald and the others were required to perform 200-yard sprints within 45 seconds.
Donald said he didn't feel well, but the coaches told him to go ahead anyway, and a few minutes later he collapsed.
He allegedly received no medical assistance while the coaches held a team meeting a few yards away.

Donald died a few hours later, and in the lawsuit that followed against 13 coaches and the school district, the family claimed violation of Donald's constitutional rights to life, liberty, health, safety, and bodily integrity.
The defense asked the case be dismissed, but the court said the Constitution protects a school child from deprivation of his life caused by the callous indifference of public school officials.

So Donald's case will continue for trial, and coaches should make sure that the first down does not become the last down, and that the students for whom they are responsible do not enter the end zone.
This is Neal Chayette looking at the law.

Well, Vice President Al Gore is expecting to tour storm-ravaged areas of Maine later this week.
Maine Congressman John Balgache says the Vice President will most likely fly into Grunswick Naval Air Station on Thursday and tour the hardest-hit communities of Augusta and Lewiston.
Meanwhile, utility workers up in Maine say they're making more progress getting everyone plugged back in.
Central Maine Power says 122,000 customers are still without electricity.
Major General Earl Adams of Maine's Emergency Management Agency is with me now.
General Adams, thank you very much for joining us.
Thank you.
Tell me about the latest updates here.
How many people remain to be plugged in, and how has the progress gone?
Throughout the affected area, there's still about 135 customers that are without power.
Our shelter count has dropped to about 111 shelters that are operating now, and the count in those shelters
has dropped from a high of 2,800 to about 1,920 as we speak, so indicative for more and more people getting back online.
Any time you think when everybody is back online, what do you think for the deadline here?
The Down East area in Machias, Elton, Washington County could be a considerable time yet before they're back online, but I wouldn't dare to venture a guess as to how many days that may take.
Now, what about the conditions up there?
Are you still suffering some more roundouts and blackouts?
Not nearly as many.
We've had three or four incidents today that were caused by other things, from vehicle accidents.
Of course, the weather has come in again today with some snow and some freezing rain in parts of the affected areas, which is hampering the work a little bit.
Okay, sir, thank you very much.
Okay, we also want to thank Massachusetts for their help.
Yes, I understand we sent up a lot of units.
They sent up a lot of generators up here that were a great help in our shelters.
Okay, thank you very much.
Thank you.
That's Major General Earl Adams of Maine's Emergency Management Agency and his good neighbor, thanking Massachusetts energy companies as well.
In New Hampshire, things are slowly getting back to normal after the storm.
The number of people without power is dwindling, but more nasty weather could bring new problems.
Less than 10,000 people are in the dark this afternoon up in New Hampshire, but the freezing rain forecast for today could cause more outages.

are spending another day in the cold and in the dark.

A funeral today for Sarah Friar.
On what would have been her 22nd birthday, the family and friends of Sarah back to Wayland Church to pay their last respects to the girl who vanished 12 years ago.
A series of reports now on the funeral.
Anthony, in the small congregational church where the service was held, a white costume rested at the foot of the altar, draped with flowers of yellow, purple, and white.
It was a service that involved Sarah's friends and family, including her sister Meg, who read a poll about a message from God to all parents.
I love you for a little time, a child of mine, she said.
The youth allows the while she lives and long for when she's dead.
It may be six or seven years or twenty-two or three.
But will you till I call her back and take care of her for me?
The 75-minute service was filled with tears, with emotion, at times, laughter.
Laughter when Sarah's mother, Barbara, remembered a vibrant little girl, found excitement in everything.
Because of the size of the small church, many of Sarah's friends listened to the service outside.
I remember back in 1985, one of my stories at college was a Sarah Pryor case.
A story about the search in the woods near her whaler's home.
But now in 1998, the folks who helped search for her are the same folks that I covered back then.
They were at the church today and whaler to say goodbye.
Kathy Grunwald was one of them.
She's a family friend and did in fact search for Sarah.
My husband and I took part in the search where we literally held hands and combed the field north on Concord Road, north of her home.
I think that those memories are vivid today because her remains found in Wayland makes us all wonder, you know, had she been here all along, what about the search that we did?
And now, Grunwald says, there is somewhat of a closure, but there are still a lot of questions.
There is a pure form of anger and feeling threatened.
than perhaps we felt before, because now our attention can be shifted to what exactly did happen, and that's very difficult to take in right now.
And if Sarah Pryor is buried today, that question still remains unanswered.
Carol Lanigan, WBZ Newsradio 1030.

Mr. Magoo has always been a favorite of mine and many others of the short animated film department, with that famed Bacchus voice, the squid, the endless trap falls, which the nearsighted Mrs. Magoo always survives with.
Our hero in the days before PC began driving us all up a tree was fun for all.

Too bad it is pretty bad.
Leslie Nielsen, as good as he is in the detective series and in some other spoofish movies, tries what he may, but the story stretches on way too long.
And now with live action replacing animation, the kinds of ridiculousness we accept in cartoons becomes tiresome.
This one has to do with a stolen gem, who wants it, will find it, and what exactly Mr. Magoo has to do with it.
Don't waste your money.
We'll give Mr. Magoo, too, a dismal two out of five stars.
